Award.AwardTitle: Innovative Weak Galerkin Finite Element Methods with Application in Fluorescence Tomography
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fluorescence tomography (FT) is an emerging three-dimensional optical imaging modality that uses in vivo noninvasive depth-resolved localization and quantification of fluorescent-tagged inclusions. FT techniques have been extensively employed in early cancer detection, guidance of tumor resection, and drug monitoring and discovery. This research project aims to develop new numerical methods for computational problems arising in FT imaging. Besides fluorescence tomography, the numerical methods can be applied to solve partial differential equations that arise in various other disciplines. The models, theory, and computational methods under development in this project will be of great value in the fields of digital image processing, medical imaging, and numerical analysis, with direct applications in broad areas such as digital image and even construction industries. Students will be trained in this project.

The goal of this research project is to develop and analyze efficient numerical methods -- weak Galerkin (WG) finite element methods -- to address challenges posed by fourth-order problems arising in fluorescence tomography theory. The research will explore algorithmic advancements, new convergence theory, and imaging technology improvement, by: (1) developing robust finite element methods for a fourth order partial differential equation in the primal variable formulation for which no existing method works; (2) establishing a stability and convergence, including superconvergence, theory for the newly developed finite element methods; (3) validating and verifying the methods through collaboration with domain-specific researchers; (4) analyzing a new weak Galerkin mixed finite element method for a fourth order partial differential equation; and (5) developing application-oriented software packages, tested and validated with collaborators in the area of FT.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluorescence tomography is an emerging, in vivo noninvasive 3-D imaging technique which reconstructs images that characterize the distribution of molecules that are tagged by fluorophores. Recently, fluorescence tomography techniques have been extensively employed in early cancer detection, guidance of tumor resection as well as drug monitoring and discovery. The project has innovated and analyzed the efficient numerical methods rooted in advanced computational mathematics in the framework of weak Galerkin finite element methods to address challenges in fluorescence tomography theory so as to empower biologists and engineers to conduct fundamental and applied research in this area. Besides fluorescence tomography, the developed numerical methods can be applied to solve partial differential equations that arise in various other disciplines. The models, theory, and computational methods developed in this project will be valuable in the fields of digital image processing, medical imaging, and numerical analysis, with direct applications in broad areas such as digital image and even construction industries.  

 

The outcome of this project consists of new algorithm development with mathematical convergence for problems related to fluorescence tomography. The published work resulted from this grant includes:(1) the development of an innovative and effective numerical algorithm for a fourth order problem arising from fluorescence tomography; (2) the design and analysis of new numerical algorithm for second order elliptic equations in non-divergence form based on a discrete weak Hessian operator locally constructed by following the weak Galerkin framework; (3) the development of a bivariate spline method for numerical solving of second order elliptic partial differential equations in non-divergence form; (4)a locking-free numerical method for linear elasticity equations on general polygonal/polyhedral partitions by using weak Galerkin finite element methods; (5) a new discretization scheme for div-curl systems in connected domains with heterogeneous media by using the weak Galerkin finite element method; (6) a high order superconvergence for the piecewise linear Ritz-Galerkin finite element approximation for the second-order elliptic equation; (7) a new discretization scheme for time-harmonic Maxwell equations using the weak Galerkin finite element method; and (8) a superconvergence error estimate for the gradient approximation of the second order elliptic problem in three dimensions discretized by using weak Galerkin finite element methods on uniform and non-uniform Cartesian partitions.

The research outcome from the funded research has the potential of helping develop improved technologies in fluorescence tomography through computational simulation. It further has positive impacts for related applied problems in medical sciences, biology and engineering. The results of the research have been disseminated through a variety of channels including participation to conferences and workshops, publication in mathematical and engineering journals.  The PI has incorporated her research perspective and experience into her teaching and student supervision. The PI has worked with three undergraduate students, with two of them supported directly by this grant. The undergraduate students made good contributions to the success of this project by performing mathematical analysis on some numerical methods, and by solving problems on computers through code development in MatLab. The undergraduate students received solid training through their involvement in this project.
